content:
I think I am done fixing the following issue: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/93211 (just a small testcase).

Since it is my first contribution to rust and in general my first PR, I am a bit unsure even though I read the compiler guide.

I am not 100% sure if my solution is correct (./x.py test --stage 0 library/std) succeeds, all tests pass, and the error does not occur anymore. But since I had to work with environmental variables I am not sure if it now works in general, especially since the fix checks for the "CI" variable.
Should I just create my PR (since it is just a minor testcase fix, nothing huge) and wait for feedback, or is there a way, that a mentor or higher skilled person would take a first "look" and maybe give me some tips, before I create the PR?
You can also run ./x.py test tidy to run some formatting and style checks.
and you could also set the CI variable locally to see if it fails as expected

The 8472 said:

You can also run ./x.py test tidy to run some formatting and style checks.

image.png

Does that look about right?

The 8472 said:

and you could also set the CI variable locally to see if it fails as expected

Here is where I am a bit stuck. Would I set the environment variable in the config.toml? @The 8472

It's an operating system concept, each process has environment variables, with a copy inherited by its children. Since you're using powershell you can set it there before spawning x.py
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_environment_variables?view=powershell-7.2

@The 8472 very kind for your help.

image.png

I set the variable like that. And it worked!
Means I can go for the PR?
Assuming "it worked" means the test failed, sure. the PR is the getting-approval step. Asking for approval to request approval does feel a bit silly ;)

[Quotingâ€¦]
Yeah, sorry for the bunch of questions, kinda nervous, haha
